an4.111:1.1.pli: Atha kho kesi assadammasārathi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho kesiṃ assadammasārathiṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an4.111:1.1.eng: Then Kesi the horse trainer went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

an4.111:1.2.eng: “Kesi, you’re known as a horse trainer.

an4.111:1.3.pli: Kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, kesi, assadammaṃ vinesī”ti?
an4.111:1.3.eng: Just how do you guide a horse in training?”

an4.111:1.4.pli: “Ahaṃ kho, bhante, assadammaṃ saṇhenapi vinemi, pharusenapi vinemi, saṇhapharusenapi vinemī”ti.
an4.111:1.4.eng: “Sir, I guide a horse in training sometimes gently, sometimes harshly, and sometimes both gently and harshly.”

an4.111:1.5.pli: “Sace te, kesi, assadammo saṇhena vinayaṃ na upeti, pharusena vinayaṃ na upeti, saṇhapharusena vinayaṃ na upeti, kinti naṃ karosī”ti?
an4.111:1.5.eng: “Kesi, what do you do with a horse in training that doesn’t follow these forms of training?”

an4.111:1.6.pli: “Sace me, bhante, assadammo saṇhena vinayaṃ na upeti, pharusena vinayaṃ na upeti, saṇhapharusena vinayaṃ na upeti;

an4.111:1.7.eng: “In that case, sir, I kill it.

an4.111:1.9.eng: So that I don’t disgrace my tradition.

an4.111:2.1.eng: But sir, the Buddha is the supreme guide for those fit for training.

an4.111:2.2.pli: Kathaṃ pana, bhante, bhagavā purisadammaṃ vinetī”ti?
an4.111:2.2.eng: Just how do you guide a person in training?”

an4.111:2.3.pli: “Ahaṃ kho, kesi, purisadammaṃ saṇhenapi vinemi, pharusenapi vinemi, saṇhapharusenapi vinemi.
an4.111:2.3.eng: “Kesi, I guide a person in training sometimes gently, sometimes harshly, and sometimes both gently and harshly.

an4.111:2.5.pli: iti kāyasucaritaṃ iti kāyasucaritassa vipāko, iti vacīsucaritaṃ iti vacīsucaritassa vipāko, iti manosucaritaṃ iti manosucaritassa vipāko, iti devā, iti manussāti.
an4.111:2.5.eng: ‘This is good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind. This is the result of good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind. This is life as a god. This is life as a human.’

an4.111:2.7.pli: iti kāyaduccaritaṃ iti kāyaduccaritassa vipāko, iti vacīduccaritaṃ iti vacīduccaritassa vipāko, iti manoduccaritaṃ iti manoduccaritassa vipāko, iti nirayo, iti tiracchānayoni, iti pettivisayoti.
an4.111:2.7.eng: ‘This is bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind. This is the result of bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind. This is life in hell. This is life as an animal. This is life as a ghost.’

an4.111:3.1.eng: The both gentle and harsh way is this:

an4.111:3.2.pli: iti kāyasucaritaṃ iti kāyasucaritassa vipāko, iti kāyaduccaritaṃ iti kāyaduccaritassa vipāko, iti vacīsucaritaṃ iti vacīsucaritassa vipāko, iti vacīduccaritaṃ iti vacīduccaritassa vipāko, iti manosucaritaṃ iti manosucaritassa vipāko, iti manoduccaritaṃ iti manoduccaritassa vipāko, iti devā, iti manussā, iti nirayo, iti tiracchānayoni, iti pettivisayo”ti.
an4.111:3.2.eng: ‘This is good conduct … this is bad conduct …’”

an4.111:4.1.pli: “Sace te, bhante, purisadammo saṇhena vinayaṃ na upeti, pharusena vinayaṃ na upeti, saṇhapharusena vinayaṃ na upeti, kinti naṃ bhagavā karotī”ti?
an4.111:4.1.eng: “Sir, what do you do with a person in training who doesn’t follow these forms of training?”

an4.111:4.2.pli: “Sace me, kesi, purisadammo saṇhena vinayaṃ na upeti, pharusena vinayaṃ na upeti, saṇhapharusena vinayaṃ na upeti, hanāmi naṃ, kesī”ti.
an4.111:4.2.eng: “In that case, Kesi, I kill them.”

an4.111:4.3.eng: “Sir, it’s not appropriate for the Buddha to kill living creatures.

an4.111:4.7.eng: it’s not appropriate for a Realized One to kill living creatures.

an4.111:4.8.pli: Api ca yo purisadammo saṇhena vinayaṃ na upeti, pharusena vinayaṃ na upeti, saṇhapharusena vinayaṃ na upeti, na taṃ tathāgato vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññati, nāpi viññū sabrahmacārī vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññanti.
an4.111:4.8.eng: But when a person in training doesn’t follow any of these forms of training, the Realized One doesn’t think they’re worth advising or instructing, and neither do their sensible spiritual companions.

an4.111:4.9.eng: For it is killing in the training of the Noble One

an4.111:4.10.pli: yaṃ na tathāgato vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññati, nāpi viññū sabrahmacārī vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññantī”ti.
an4.111:4.10.eng: when the Realized One doesn’t think they’re worth advising or instructing, and neither do their sensible spiritual companions.”

an4.111:5.2.pli: yaṃ na tathāgato vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññati, nāpi viññū sabrahmacārī vattabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññantīti.
an4.111:5.2.eng: when the Realized One doesn’t think they’re worth advising or instructing, and neither do their sensible spiritual companions.

an4.111:5.3.pli: Abhikkantaṃ, bhante, abhikkantaṃ, bhante …pe… upāsakaṃ maṃ, bhante, bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
an4.111:5.3.eng: Excellent, sir! … From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

an4.112:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño bhadro assājānīyo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.112:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a fine royal thoroughbred with four factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and reckoned a factor of kingship.

an4.112:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño bhadro assājānīyo rājāraho hoti, rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.112:1.4.eng: A fine royal thoroughbred with these four factors is worthy of a king. …

an4.112:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an4.112:2.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with four qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an4.112:2.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an4.112:2.4.eng: A mendicant with these four qualities … is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an4.113:1.1.pli: “Cattārome, bhikkhave, bhadrā assājānīyā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an4.113:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four fine thoroughbreds are found in the world.

an4.113:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco bhadro assājānīyo patodacchāyaṃ disvā saṃvijjati saṃvegaṃ āpajjati:
an4.113:1.3.eng: One fine thoroughbred is moved to act when it sees the shadow of the goad, thinking:

an4.113:1.4.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho maṃ ajja assadammasārathi kāraṇaṃ kāressati, kimassāhaṃ paṭikaromī’ti.
an4.113:1.4.eng: ‘What task will the horse trainer have me do today? How should I respond?’

an4.113:1.5.pli: Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhadro assājānīyo hoti.
an4.113:1.5.eng: Some fine thoroughbreds are like that.

an4.113:1.6.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo bhadro assājānīyo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an4.113:1.6.eng: This is the first fine thoroughbred found in the world.

an4.113:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhadro assājānīyo na heva kho patodacchāyaṃ disvā saṃvijjati saṃvegaṃ āpajjati, api ca kho lomavedhaviddho saṃvijjati saṃvegaṃ āpajjati:
an4.113:2.1.eng: Furthermore, one fine thoroughbred isn’t moved to act when it sees the shadow of the goad, but only when its hairs are struck, thinking:

an4.113:2.2.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho maṃ ajja assadammasārathi kāraṇaṃ kāressati, kimassāhaṃ paṭikaromī’ti.
an4.113:2.2.eng: ‘What task will the horse trainer have me do today? How should I respond?’

an4.113:2.3.pli: Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhadro assājānīyo hoti.
an4.113:2.3.eng: Some fine thoroughbreds are like that.

an4.113:2.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo bhadro assājānīyo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an4.113:2.4.eng: This is the second fine thoroughbred found in the world.

an4.113:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhadro assājānīyo na heva kho patodacchāyaṃ disvā saṃvijjati saṃvegaṃ āpajjati nāpi lomavedhaviddho saṃvijjati saṃvegaṃ āpajjati, api ca kho cammavedhaviddho saṃvijjati saṃvegaṃ āpajjati:
an4.113:3.1.eng: Furthermore, one fine thoroughbred isn’t moved to act when it sees the shadow of the goad, nor when its hairs are struck, but only when its hide is struck, thinking:

an4.113:3.2.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho maṃ ajja assadammasārathi kāraṇaṃ kāressati, kimassāhaṃ paṭikaromī’ti.
an4.113:3.2.eng: ‘What task will the horse trainer have me do today? How should I respond?’

an4.113:3.3.pli: Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhadro assājānīyo hoti.
an4.113:3.3.eng: Some fine thoroughbreds are like that.

an4.113:3.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyo bhadro assājānīyo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an4.113:3.4.eng: This is the third fine thoroughbred found in the world.

an4.113:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhadro assājānīyo na heva kho patodacchāyaṃ disvā saṃvijjati saṃvegaṃ āpajjati nāpi lomavedhaviddho saṃvijjati saṃvegaṃ āpajjati nāpi cammavedhaviddho saṃvijjati saṃvegaṃ āpajjati, api ca kho aṭṭhivedhaviddho saṃvijjati saṃvegaṃ āpajjati:
an4.113:4.1.eng: Furthermore, one fine thoroughbred isn’t moved to act when it sees the shadow of the goad, nor when its hairs are struck, nor when its hide is struck, but only when its bone is struck, thinking:

an4.113:4.2.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho maṃ ajja assadammasārathi kāraṇaṃ kāressati, kimassāhaṃ paṭikaromī’ti.
an4.113:4.2.eng: ‘What task will the horse trainer have me do today? How should I respond?’

an4.113:4.3.pli: Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhadro assājānīyo hoti.
an4.113:4.3.eng: Some fine thoroughbreds are like that.

an4.113:4.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, catuttho bhadro assājānīyo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an4.113:4.4.eng: This is the fourth fine thoroughbred found in the world.

an4.113:4.5.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro bhadrā assājānīyā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an4.113:4.5.eng: These are the four fine thoroughbreds found in the world.

an4.113:5.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, cattārome bhadrā purisājānīyā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an4.113:5.1.eng: In the same way, these four fine thoroughbred people are found in the world.

an4.113:5.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco bhadro purisājānīyo suṇāti:
an4.113:5.3.eng: One fine thoroughbred person hears about

an4.113:5.4.pli: ‘amukasmiṃ nāma gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā puriso vā dukkhito vā kālaṅkato vā’ti.
an4.113:5.4.eng: the suffering or death of a woman or man in such and such village or town.

an4.113:5.5.eng: They’re moved to act by this,

an4.113:5.7.pli: Pahitatto kāyena ceva paramasaccaṃ sacchikaroti, paññāya ca ativijjha passati.
an4.113:5.7.eng: Applying themselves, they directly realize the ultimate truth, and see it with penetrating wisdom.

an4.113:5.8.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, bhadro assājānīyo patodacchāyaṃ disvā saṃvijjati saṃvegaṃ āpajjati;
an4.113:5.8.eng: This individual is like the fine thoroughbred

an4.113:5.9.pli: tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ bhadraṃ purisājānīyaṃ vadāmi.
an4.113:5.9.eng: that’s shaken when it sees the shadow of the goad.

an4.113:5.10.pli: Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhadro purisājānīyo hoti.
an4.113:5.10.eng: Some fine thoroughbred people are like that.

an4.113:5.11.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo bhadro purisājānīyo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an4.113:5.11.eng: This is the first fine thoroughbred person found in the world.

an4.113:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhadro purisājānīyo na heva kho suṇāti:
an4.113:6.1.eng: Furthermore, one fine thoroughbred person doesn’t hear about

an4.113:6.2.pli: ‘amukasmiṃ nāma gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā puriso vā dukkhito vā kālaṅkato vā’ti, api ca kho sāmaṃ passati itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā dukkhitaṃ vā kālaṅkataṃ vā.
an4.113:6.2.eng: the suffering or death of a woman or man in such and such village or town, but they see it themselves.

an4.113:6.3.eng: They’re moved to act by this,

an4.113:6.5.pli: Pahitatto kāyena ceva paramasaccaṃ sacchikaroti, paññāya ca ativijjha passati.
an4.113:6.5.eng: Applying themselves, they directly realize the ultimate truth, and see it with penetrating wisdom.

an4.113:6.6.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, bhadro assājānīyo lomavedhaviddho saṃvijjati saṃvegaṃ āpajjati;
an4.113:6.6.eng: This person is like the fine thoroughbred that’s moved to act

an4.113:6.7.pli: tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ bhadraṃ purisājānīyaṃ vadāmi.

an4.113:6.8.pli: Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhadro purisājānīyo hoti.
an4.113:6.8.eng: Some fine thoroughbred people are like that.

an4.113:6.9.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo bhadro purisājānīyo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an4.113:6.9.eng: This is the second fine thoroughbred person found in the world.

an4.113:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhadro purisājānīyo na heva kho suṇāti:
an4.113:7.1.eng: Furthermore, one fine thoroughbred person doesn’t hear about

an4.113:7.2.pli: ‘amukasmiṃ nāma gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā puriso vā dukkhito vā kālaṅkato vā’ti, nāpi sāmaṃ passati itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā dukkhitaṃ vā kālaṅkataṃ vā, api ca khvassa ñāti vā sālohito vā dukkhito vā hoti kālaṅkato vā.
an4.113:7.2.eng: the suffering or death of a woman or man in such and such village or town, nor do they see it themselves, but it happens to their own relative or family member.

an4.113:7.3.eng: They’re moved to act by this,

an4.113:7.5.pli: Pahitatto kāyena ceva paramasaccaṃ sacchikaroti, paññāya ca ativijjha passati.
an4.113:7.5.eng: Applying themselves, they directly realize the ultimate truth, and see it with penetrating wisdom.

an4.113:7.6.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, bhadro assājānīyo cammavedhaviddho saṃvijjati saṃvegaṃ āpajjati;
an4.113:7.6.eng: This person is like the fine thoroughbred that’s moved to act

an4.113:7.7.pli: tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ bhadraṃ purisājānīyaṃ vadāmi.

an4.113:7.8.pli: Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhadro purisājānīyo hoti.
an4.113:7.8.eng: Some fine thoroughbred people are like that.

an4.113:7.9.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyo bhadro purisājānīyo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an4.113:7.9.eng: This is the third fine thoroughbred person found in the world.

an4.113:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhadro purisājānīyo na heva kho suṇāti:
an4.113:8.1.eng: Furthermore, one fine thoroughbred person doesn’t hear about

an4.113:8.2.pli: ‘amukasmiṃ nāma gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā puriso vā dukkhito vā kālaṅkato vā’ti, nāpi sāmaṃ passati itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā dukkhitaṃ vā kālaṅkataṃ vā, nāpissa ñāti vā sālohito vā dukkhito vā hoti kālaṅkato vā, api ca kho sāmaññeva phuṭṭho hoti sārīrikāhi vedanāhi dukkhāhi tibbāhi kharāhi kaṭukāhi asātāhi amanāpāhi pāṇaharāhi.
an4.113:8.2.eng: the suffering or death of a woman or man in such and such village or town, nor do they see it themselves, nor does it happen to their own relative or family member, but they themselves are afflicted with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.

an4.113:8.3.eng: They’re moved to act by this,

an4.113:8.5.pli: Pahitatto kāyena ceva paramasaccaṃ sacchikaroti, paññāya ca ativijjha passati.
an4.113:8.5.eng: Applying themselves, they directly realize the ultimate truth, and see it with penetrating wisdom.

an4.113:8.6.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, bhadro assājānīyo aṭṭhivedhaviddho saṃvijjati saṃvegaṃ āpajjati;
an4.113:8.6.eng: This person is like the fine thoroughbred that’s moved to act

an4.113:8.7.pli: tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ bhadraṃ purisājānīyaṃ vadāmi.

an4.113:8.8.pli: Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhadro purisājānīyo hoti.
an4.113:8.8.eng: Some fine thoroughbred people are like that.

an4.113:8.9.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, catuttho bhadro purisājānīyo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an4.113:8.9.eng: This is the fourth fine thoroughbred person found in the world.

an4.113:8.10.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro bhadrā purisājānīyā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
an4.113:8.10.eng: These are the four fine thoroughbred people found in the world.”

an4.114:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño nāgo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.114:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a royal bull elephant with four factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is reckoned a factor of kingship.

an4.114:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo sotā ca hoti, hantā ca, khantā ca, gantā ca.
an4.114:1.3.eng: A royal bull elephant listens, destroys, endures, and goes fast.

an4.114:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo sotā hoti?
an4.114:2.1.eng: And how does a royal bull elephant listen?

an4.114:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo yamenaṃ hatthidammasārathi kāraṇaṃ kāreti—
an4.114:2.2.eng: It’s when a royal bull elephant pays attention, applies the mind, concentrates wholeheartedly, and actively listens to whatever task the elephant trainer has it do,

an4.114:2.3.pli: yadi vā katapubbaṃ yadi vā akatapubbaṃ—
an4.114:2.3.eng: whether or not it has done it before.

an4.114:2.4.pli: taṃ aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasoto suṇāti.

an4.114:2.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo sotā hoti.
an4.114:2.5.eng: That’s how a royal bull elephant listens.

an4.114:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo hantā hoti?
an4.114:3.1.eng: And how does a royal bull elephant destroy?

an4.114:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato hatthimpi hanati, hatthāruhampi hanati, assampi hanati, assāruhampi hanati, rathampi hanati, rathikampi hanati, pattikampi hanati.
an4.114:3.2.eng: It’s when a royal bull elephant in battle destroys elephants with their riders, horses with their riders, chariots and charioteers, and foot soldiers.

an4.114:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo hantā hoti.
an4.114:3.3.eng: That’s how a royal bull elephant destroys.

an4.114:4.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo khantā hoti?
an4.114:4.1.eng: And how does a royal bull elephant endure?

an4.114:4.2.pli: Idha bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato khamo hoti sattippahārānaṃ asippahārānaṃ usuppahārānaṃ pharasuppahārānaṃ bheripaṇavasaṅkhatiṇavaninnādasaddānaṃ.
an4.114:4.2.eng: It’s when a royal bull elephant in battle endures being struck by spears, swords, arrows, and axes; it endures the thunder of the drums, kettledrums, horns, and cymbals.

an4.114:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo khantā hoti.
an4.114:4.3.eng: That’s how a royal bull elephant endures.

an4.114:5.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo gantā hoti?
an4.114:5.1.eng: And how does a royal bull elephant go fast?

an4.114:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo yamenaṃ hatthidammasārathi disaṃ peseti—
an4.114:5.2.eng: It’s when a royal bull elephant swiftly goes in whatever direction the elephant trainer sends it,

an4.114:5.3.pli: yadi vā gatapubbaṃ yadi vā agatapubbaṃ—
an4.114:5.3.eng: whether or not it has been there before.

an4.114:5.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo gantā hoti.
an4.114:5.5.eng: That’s how a royal bull elephant goes fast.

an4.114:5.6.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño nāgo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.114:5.6.eng: A royal bull elephant with four factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is reckoned a factor of kingship.

an4.114:6.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an4.114:6.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with four qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an4.114:6.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sotā ca hoti, hantā ca, khantā ca, gantā ca.
an4.114:6.3.eng: A mendicant listens, destroys, endures, and goes fast.

an4.114:7.1.eng: And how does a mendicant listen?

an4.114:7.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tathāgatappavedite dhammavinaye desiyamāne aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasoto dhammaṃ suṇāti.
an4.114:7.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant pays attention, applies the mind, concentrates wholeheartedly, and actively listens when the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One is being taught.

an4.114:7.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sotā hoti.

an4.114:8.1.eng: And how does a mendicant destroy?

an4.114:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti hanati byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gameti, uppannaṃ byāpādavitakkaṃ …pe… uppannaṃ vihiṃsāvitakkaṃ …pe… uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti hanati byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gameti.
an4.114:8.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t tolerate a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought. They don’t tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.

an4.114:8.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu hantā hoti.

an4.114:9.1.eng: And how does a mendicant endure?

an4.114:9.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khamo hoti sītassa uṇhassa jighacchāya pipāsāya, ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṃ duruttānaṃ durāgatānaṃ vacanapathānaṃ uppannānaṃ sārīrikānaṃ vedanānaṃ dukkhānaṃ tibbānaṃ kharānaṃ kaṭukānaṃ asātānaṃ amanāpānaṃ pāṇaharānaṃ adhivāsakajātiko hoti.
an4.114:9.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant endures cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; rude and unwelcome criticism; and they put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.

an4.114:9.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khantā hoti.

an4.114:10.1.eng: And how does a mendicant go fast?

an4.114:10.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāyaṃ disā agatapubbā iminā dīghena addhunā yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānaṃ, taṃ khippaññeva gantā hoti.
an4.114:10.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant swiftly goes in the direction they’ve never gone before in all this long time; that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.

an4.114:10.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gantā hoti.
an4.114:10.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant goes fast.

an4.114:10.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an4.114:10.4.eng: A mendicant with these four qualities … is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an4.115:1.3.eng: There is a thing that’s unpleasant to do,

an4.115:1.5.eng: There is a thing that’s unpleasant to do,

an4.115:1.7.eng: There is a thing that’s pleasant to do,

an4.115:1.9.eng: There is a thing that’s pleasant to do,

an4.115:2.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṃ ṭhānaṃ amanāpaṃ kātuṃ;
an4.115:2.1.eng: Take the thing that’s unpleasant to do,

an4.115:2.3.pli: idaṃ, bhikkhave, ṭhānaṃ ubhayeneva na kattabbaṃ maññati.
an4.115:2.3.eng: This is regarded as a thing that shouldn’t be done on both grounds:

an4.115:2.6.eng: and because doing it proves harmful.

an4.115:2.8.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, ṭhānaṃ ubhayeneva na kattabbaṃ maññati.
an4.115:2.8.eng: This is regarded as a thing that shouldn’t be done on both grounds.

an4.115:3.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṃ ṭhānaṃ amanāpaṃ kātuṃ;
an4.115:3.1.eng: Next, take the thing that’s unpleasant to do,

an4.115:3.3.pli: imasmiṃ, bhikkhave, ṭhāne bālo ca paṇḍito ca veditabbo purisathāme purisavīriye purisaparakkame.
an4.115:3.3.eng: It is here that you can tell who is foolish and who is astute in regard to human strength, energy, and vigor.

an4.115:3.5.eng: ‘Despite the fact that this thing is unpleasant to do,

an4.115:3.6.pli: atha carahidaṃ ṭhānaṃ kayiramānaṃ atthāya saṃvattatī’ti.

an4.115:3.8.pli: Tassa taṃ ṭhānaṃ akayiramānaṃ anatthāya saṃvattati.

an4.115:3.9.pli: Paṇḍito ca kho, bhikkhave, iti paṭisañcikkhati:

an4.115:3.10.eng: ‘Even though this thing is unpleasant to do,

an4.115:3.11.pli: atha carahidaṃ ṭhānaṃ kayiramānaṃ atthāya saṃvattatī’ti.

an4.115:3.13.pli: Tassa taṃ ṭhānaṃ kayiramānaṃ atthāya saṃvattati.

an4.115:4.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṃ ṭhānaṃ manāpaṃ kātuṃ;
an4.115:4.1.eng: Next, take the thing that’s pleasant to do,

an4.115:4.3.pli: imasmimpi, bhikkhave, ṭhāne bālo ca paṇḍito ca veditabbo purisathāme purisavīriye purisaparakkame.
an4.115:4.3.eng: It is here that you can tell who is foolish and who is astute in regard to human strength, energy, and vigor.

an4.115:4.5.eng: ‘Even though this thing is pleasant to do,

an4.115:4.6.pli: atha carahidaṃ ṭhānaṃ kayiramānaṃ anatthāya saṃvattatī’ti.

an4.115:4.8.pli: Tassa taṃ ṭhānaṃ kayiramānaṃ anatthāya saṃvattati.

an4.115:4.9.pli: Paṇḍito ca kho, bhikkhave, iti paṭisañcikkhati:

an4.115:4.10.eng: ‘Despite the fact that this thing is pleasant to do,

an4.115:4.11.pli: atha carahidaṃ ṭhānaṃ kayiramānaṃ anatthāya saṃvattatī’ti.

an4.115:4.13.pli: Tassa taṃ ṭhānaṃ akayiramānaṃ atthāya saṃvattati.

an4.115:5.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṃ ṭhānaṃ manāpaṃ kātuṃ, tañca kayiramānaṃ atthāya saṃvattati—
an4.115:5.1.eng: Next, take the thing that’s pleasant to do, and doing it proves beneficial.

an4.115:5.2.pli: idaṃ, bhikkhave, ṭhānaṃ ubhayeneva kattabbaṃ maññati.
an4.115:5.2.eng: This is regarded as a thing that should be done on both grounds:

an4.115:5.3.pli: Yampidaṃ ṭhānaṃ manāpaṃ kātuṃ, imināpi naṃ kattabbaṃ maññati;

an4.115:5.4.pli: yampidaṃ ṭhānaṃ kayiramānaṃ atthāya saṃvattati, imināpi naṃ kattabbaṃ maññati.
an4.115:5.4.eng: and because doing it proves beneficial.

an4.115:5.5.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, ṭhānaṃ ubhayeneva kattabbaṃ maññati.
an4.115:5.5.eng: This is regarded as a thing that should be done on both grounds.

an4.116:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should be diligent in four situations.

an4.116:1.3.eng: Give up bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind; and develop good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

an4.116:1.9.eng: Give up wrong view; and develop right view.

an4.116:2.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno kāyaduccaritaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti kāyasucaritaṃ bhāvitaṃ, vacīduccaritaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti vacīsucaritaṃ bhāvitaṃ, manoduccaritaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti manosucaritaṃ bhāvitaṃ, micchādiṭṭhi pahīnā hoti sammādiṭṭhi bhāvitā, so na bhāyati samparāyikassa maraṇassā”ti.
an4.116:2.1.eng: A mendicant who has done these things does not fear death in lives to come.”

an4.117:1.1.pli: “Catūsu, bhikkhave, ṭhānesu attarūpena appamādo sati cetaso ārakkho karaṇīyo.
an4.117:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, in your own way you should practice diligence, mindfulness, and guarding of the mind in four situations.

an4.117:1.3.pli: ‘Mā me rajanīyesu dhammesu cittaṃ rajjī’ti attarūpena appamādo sati cetaso ārakkho karaṇīyo;
an4.117:1.3.eng: ‘May my mind not be aroused by things that arouse greed.’ In your own way you should practice diligence, mindfulness, and guarding of the mind.

an4.117:1.4.pli: ‘mā me dosanīyesu dhammesu cittaṃ dussī’ti attarūpena appamādo sati cetaso ārakkho karaṇīyo;
an4.117:1.4.eng: ‘May my mind not be angered by things that provoke hate.’ …

an4.117:1.5.pli: ‘mā me mohanīyesu dhammesu cittaṃ muyhī’ti attarūpena appamādo sati cetaso ārakkho karaṇīyo;
an4.117:1.5.eng: ‘May my mind not be deluded by things that promote delusion.’ …

an4.117:1.6.pli: ‘mā me madanīyesu dhammesu cittaṃ majjī’ti attarūpena appamādo sati cetaso ārakkho karaṇīyo.
an4.117:1.6.eng: ‘May my mind not be intoxicated by things that intoxicate.’ …

an4.117:2.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno rajanīyesu dhammesu cittaṃ na rajjati vītarāgattā, dosanīyesu dhammesu cittaṃ na dussati vītadosattā, mohanīyesu dhammesu cittaṃ na muyhati vītamohattā, madanīyesu dhammesu cittaṃ na majjati vītamadattā, so na chambhati na kampati na vedhati na santāsaṃ āpajjati, na ca pana samaṇavacanahetupi gacchatī”ti.
an4.117:2.1.eng: When a mendicant’s mind is no longer affected by greed, hate, delusion, or intoxication because they’ve got rid of these things, they don’t shake, tremble, quake, or get nervous, nor are they persuaded by the teachings of other ascetics.”

an4.118:1.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, saddhassa kulaputtassa dassanīyāni saṃvejanīyāni ṭhānāni.
an4.118:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a faithful gentleman should go to see these four inspiring places.

an4.118:1.3.pli: ‘Idha tathāgato jāto’ti, bhikkhave, saddhassa kulaputtassa dassanīyaṃ saṃvejanīyaṃ ṭhānaṃ.
an4.118:1.3.eng: Thinking: ‘Here the Realized One was born!’—that is an inspiring place.

an4.118:1.4.pli: ‘Idha tathāgato anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti, bhikkhave, saddhassa kulaputtassa dassanīyaṃ saṃvejanīyaṃ ṭhānaṃ.
an4.118:1.4.eng: Thinking: ‘Here the Realized One became awakened as a supreme fully awakened Buddha!’—that is an inspiring place.

an4.118:1.5.pli: ‘Idha tathāgato anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattesī’ti, bhikkhave, saddhassa kulaputtassa dassanīyaṃ saṃvejanīyaṃ ṭhānaṃ.
an4.118:1.5.eng: Thinking: ‘Here the Realized One rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma!’—that is an inspiring place.

an4.118:1.6.pli: ‘Idha tathāgato anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbuto’ti, bhikkhave, saddhassa kulaputtassa dassanīyaṃ saṃvejanīyaṃ ṭhānaṃ.
an4.118:1.6.eng: Thinking: ‘Here the Realized One was fully quenched in the element of extinguishment, with no residue!’—that is an inspiring place.

an4.118:1.7.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri saddhassa kulaputtassa dassanīyāni saṃvejanīyāni ṭhānānī”ti.
an4.118:1.7.eng: These are the four inspiring places that a faithful gentleman should go to see.”

an4.119:1.3.eng: The perils of rebirth, old age, sickness, and death.
